notes: African Elephants are the largest land animals on Earth.
They are known for their large ears, which help to regulate their body temperature.
Cheetahs are known for their incredible speed, which they use to catch their prey.
They have a unique black 'tear mark' under their eyes which helps to reflect the sun's glare while hunting.
Lions are known as the king of the jungle, although they primarily live in grasslands and savannas.
Male lions have a distinctive mane, which is a sign of maturity and health.
Giraffes are the tallest land animals, reaching heights of up to 18 feet (5.5 meters).
Their long necks allow them to browse on leaves and shoots high in the trees.
Blue Whales are the largest animals to have ever existed, larger than any dinosaur.
They can reach lengths of up to 100 feet (30 meters) and weigh as much as 200 tons.
The Wandering Albatross has the largest wingspan of any living bird, reaching up to 11 feet (3.4 meters).
They are known for their long-distance flights across the Southern Ocean.
Bats are the only mammals capable of sustained flight.
There are over 1,200 species of bats, making up about 20% of all mammal species.
Whale Sharks are the largest species of shark, growing up to 40 feet (12 meters) in length.
They are filter feeders and primarily eat plankton.
The Bee Hummingbird is the smallest bird, measuring about 2.4 inches (6.1 cm) in length.
They are native to Cuba and the Isla de la Juventud.
Emperor Penguins are the largest species of penguin, standing up to 48 inches (122 cm) tall.
They are known for their long treks across the Antarctic ice to breeding colonies.
Saltwater Crocodiles are the largest reptiles, growing up to 23 feet (7 meters) in length.
They are found in saltwater habitats and brackish wetlands in Southeast Asia and Australia.
